Article.ArticleTitle: The protective effects of β-caryophyllene on LPS-induced primary microglia M<sub>1</sub>/M<sub>2</sub> imbalance: A mechanistic evaluation.

AbstractText: Neuroinflammation is observed as a routine characterization of neurodegenerative disorders such as dementia, multiple sclerosis (MS) and Alzheimer's diseases (AD). Scientific evidence propounds both of the neuromodulatory and immunomodulatory effects of CB<sub>2</sub> in the immune system. β-Caryophyllene (BCP) is a dietary selective CB<sub>2</sub> agonist, which deserves the anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects at both low and high doses through activation of the CB<sub>2</sub> receptor.

In this study, we investigated the protective effects of a broad range concentration of BCP against LPS-induced primary microglia cells inflammation and M<sub>1</sub>/M<sub>2</sub> imbalance and identifying the portion of the involvement of related signaling pathways on BCP effects using pharmacological antagonists of CB<sub>2</sub>, PPAR-γ, and sphingomyelinase (SMase).

The protective effects of BCP on LPS-induced microglia imbalance is provided by the M<sub>2</sub> healing phenotype of microglia, releasing the anti-inflammatory (IL-10, Arg-1, and urea) and anti-oxidant (GSH) parameters and reducing the inflammatory (IL-1β, TNF-α, PGE<sub>2</sub>, iNOS and NO) and oxidative (ROS) biomarkers. Moreover, we showed that BCP exerts its effects through CB<sub>2</sub> receptors which overproduction of ceramides by SMase at middle to higher concentrations of BCP reduce the protective activity of BCP and results in the activation of the PPAR-γ pathway.

In conclusion, the low concentration of BCP has higher selective anti-inflammatory effects rather than high levels. On this occasion, BCP by modulating the microglia is able to have potential therapeutic effects in neuro-inflammation conditions and microglia cells such as MS and AD.
